If your experience “cannot load page” errors when navigating between entries in this documentation, then the culprit is very likely an activated ad blocker. Many of the documented classes and services have names related to advertising terms. We found that this can trigger ad blockers. So please disable your adblocker if you have issues.
To serve advertisements using the Adition AdSDK you will typically:
Add the package dependencies (public, without dSYM) or integrate xcframework via Nexus (private, with dSYM).
Initialize the
Request the creation of an
from
passing
Apps using this AdSDK must be built at least for deployment target of iOS 14.0.
You can follow the AdSDK integration
with code examples where you will create your first application using the AdSDK.
Starting from IOS 14, you, as a developer, are required to ask for permission to track a user. Learn more in Apple’s
Please read Apple’s definition of tracking carefully, as it may not be the same as yours.

“Tracking refers to the act of linking user or device data collected from your app with user or device data collected from other companies’ apps, websites, or offline properties for targeted advertising or advertising measurement purposes. Tracking also refers to sharing user or device data with data brokers.” – from Apple’s
In other words, if you do not share user data with other companies or services, you are not doing tracking.
The SDK offers a wide range of functionality that can be used for tracking. If you use tracking in your application, you are responsible for:
1. Adding a privacy manifest to your project.
If you use tracking, you need to indicate this info into the Privacy Manifest. In order to do this:
key should be set to
key should contain an array with the element
Learn more in Apple’s
2. Passing
Even if the user denies the tracking, IOS will not block URL requests for
domain from the SDK. In addition to adding this domain to the privacy manifest, you should pass the
parameter to the SDK if the user has denied tracking. You can do this using the
method.

inlineContent.text: Your app uses the AdSDK to request ads from an ad server.

The SDK has a built-in FIFO persistent cache that caches all possible advertising resources, such as banners on the device. The built-in cache limit is 100 MB, but you can set another size when creating an
, or change it over time using
. You can also clear the cache with
Learn more in our

We call the target URL the URL that should be shown to the user as a result of tapping on the ad.

By default, the SDK opens an external browser when processing a target URL. You can override this behaviour with your own. For example, this can be useful if you want to open your internal browser in your application to process the target URL. To do this, you pass the
to the
method.
Learn more in our
inApp-ClickURLs is a feature which allows you to specify a custom schemed tap url. An example of a custom scheme url is
. Banners with this option selected will not open a browser when it is tapped. If an app is installed on the device for the given URL schema, then this app will be opened to process the URL.

The ADITION click counting works by initially calling the ad server url which will then count the click and redirect to the banner click url. The exception to this default click handling is with inApp-ClickURL banners, as they are handled by the SDK internally which ensures the click is successfully counted and the intent fired.
There is function called
, responsible for performing any kind of
. This function use for app developer when they need to call tap event manually.

content.text: User Tagging and Conversion Tracking Features

inlineContent.text: AdSDK provides powerful functionality for user tagging and conversion tracking. You can find an example of the implementation in our

Tagging targeting is a server side tagging (user profile) feature. You are able to tag a user currently using your application with key = value tags that can be used in targeting of campaigns within the ADITION ad serving platform.
See
. This structure uses as a parameter the
method. You can pass all tags through the initializer.
Tracking is a server side feature. You are able to perform tracking request to track your conversions.
See
. The app can fire the tracking request as soon as a conversion occurs within the app via
method.
and
has ability to set global parameter, which are designed to be passed in all requests, not just individual ones. To avoid duplicating code, SDK provide
and
methods, which will modify these optional parameters:
Learn more about
in our
As App developer, you can create your own custom ad formats. For example, you can implement interactive ad formats like surveys, rotating galleries or Ads that play video.

Your custom ad format can be configured in the Adition backend. There you can define a creative template with custom JSON that will be delivered as part of the ad. For example, you could provide a way to configure some styling aspects for the ad by adding custom JSON key-value-pairs to the creative template. On the app side, you can implement your custom Ad with native technologies like Swift and SwiftUI.
As part of your custom ad you will need to provide:
a controller class which implements the
protocol;
a view which implements the
protocol.
To make the SDK aware of your ad, you need to register it with the SDK using

. Once your custom ad is registered, the SDK will  signal the Adition ad server that it can handle this new ad format for subsequent ad request. The SDK will also manage the creation of the instances of your controller and view objects in case actual ad content is delivered by the ad server.
You can find an example of the implementation of both controller and view for custom ads in the

transparency on online platforms for users in relation to recommended content – including
advertising.

. However, each of them can have additional parameters, which are called global parameters because they are specified globally for all requests. The SDK provides the ability to add global parameters once so that you don’t have to copy them when creating each request.
